6.22.23  1:48 pm   I often find new artists through looking through the Wikipedia pages for certain genres of music. For example, I found the band Television Personalities while looking at the page for "Anti-folk," and I ended up subsequently listening to their album "And Don't the Kids Just Love It," all based on the fact that the picture for Television Personalities at the top of the Wikipedia page was really cool. Basically, all this combined gave me the impression that this would be a cool band, based on their name, genre, pictures, etc. When I listened to the album, it was good, but it wasn't as good as I expected it to be, even though I couldn't possibly have had any expectations for their music. Would you say my expectations based on things that had nothing to do with the MUSIC of Television Personalities in turn made my experience of their album less enjoyable?

     Can that be applied to every artist? Is it best to just listen to a band's album cuz "fuck it?" as opposed to because "they looked cool," or "they had a cool album cover?"

6.20.23  4:22 pm   do you have any advice for young people that don't know what to do with their lives career wise?

6.20.23  4:18 pm   What do you want your songs to convey to people?

     Actually I cannot point out what makes a song tick with me. Like with the Beatles' 'Yesterday', I like it but I don't understand why. I mean objectively it's a song about longing for a happier past, which is ... kind of ... lowly(Don't take this the wrong way, I feel there is some magic in the song but I can't explain it)? Like the right thing to do may be to move on right? So isn't it kind of... giving a message that it is ok to hang onto the past? But there are also songs about moving on like 'Let it go' from Frozen, which is sung in a situation when the character absolutely should not be moving on! But I still like the song. It feels like these songs don't capture the whole truth and I am finding it difficult to explain exactly what is the difference between them and absolutely lowly songs that only talk about sex, money, etc... that make me like them. If I were to make a song, I would want to give people the truth, or rather the peace or fulfillment that they want, but I also find that whatever I put into that song will be inadequate in doing so... How do you set standards for your songs in such situations, knowing all you can throw out there is incomplete and imperfect?

      I am asking with regards to your own songs. Obviously you have high standards, a particular way of making songs that don't talk about lowly things. Like for example your song "might quit", which is about leaving and doing your own unconventional thing in a way that makes more sense to you... I cannot explain exactly but I tried doing that for some time in my life and it didn't work out... I realized it was just a pipe dream. So ...I'm ranting a bit... I guess I'm asking what is that thing of unending beauty that you can rely on?
